study.title: Single vs. extended antibiotic for prevention of surgical infection in emergent cesarean delivery
study.journal: International Journal of Pregnancy & Child Birth

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All women admitted in maternity at Ruhengeri Hospital during the study period and had agreed to be enrolled in the study after a written informed consent was obtained.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Women who had signs of ongoing infections such as chorioamnionitis, fever during labor, premature rupture of membranes for more than 18 hours and those who have had failed instrumental delivery at complete dilatation.

eligibility.population: Women undergoing emergency cesarean section at Ruhengeri Hospital, Rwanda.
eligibility.intervention: Single dose of 2g Ampicillin 15-60 minutes before skin incision (Group A) vs. multiple doses: 2g prior to skin incision with additional 1g every 8 hours over 72 hours (Group B).
eligibility.comparator: Single dose vs. multiple dose antibiotic prophylaxis.

populations.description: Single dose group: 2g Ampicillin 15-60 minutes before skin incision.
populations.comorbidities_key: HIV negative: 45.5%, HIV unknown: 49.1%; Diabetes negative: 12.4%, Diabetes unknown: 87.6%, Diabetes positive: 0%

provenance.text_snippet: 147 women received a single dose of antibiotics; 2 gms of Ampicillin 15-60 minutes before skin incision

populations.description: Multiple dose group: 2g Ampicillin 15-60 minutes before skin incision, then 1g every 8 hours for 3 days.
populations.comorbidities_key: HIV negative: 54.5%, HIV unknown: 44.6%; Diabetes negative: 11.1%, Diabetes unknown: 88.9%, Diabetes positive: 1.3%

provenance.text_snippet: 154 women received 2 gms 15-60 minutes prior to skin incision and continued 1 gm every 8 hours for 3 days

definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSI defined as fever, tenderness and swelling of the wound or loss of continuity with pus discharge. Endometritis defined as fever, tender abdomen and foul smelling discharge.

ssi_incidence.notes: SSI events detected during 30-day follow-up; most cases diagnosed on day 7.

provenance.section_heading: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups
provenance.text_snippet: Among women who received a single dose of ampicillin, 8 women (5.5 %) developed SSI during the 30 days of follow-up

ssi_incidence.notes: SSI events detected during 30-day follow-up; most cases diagnosed on day 7.

provenance.section_heading: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups
provenance.text_snippet: whereas 4 women (2.6%) developed SSI among those who received multiple doses of antibiotics

ssi_incidence.notes: Overall SSI prevalence in study population.

provenance.section_heading: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups
provenance.text_snippet: The overall prevalence of SSI in our population was 4.00%

risk_factors_effects.notes: Other covariates (education, wealth index, day/night, surgeon) not statistically significant.

provenance.section_heading: Table 4 Multiple logistic regression on predictors of SSI

interventions.description: Single dose of 2g Ampicillin 15-60 minutes before skin incision vs. multiple doses: 2g prior to skin incision with additional 1g every 8 hours over 72 hours.

provenance.section_heading: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups
provenance.text_snippet: There was no significant difference between the use of a single vs multiple doses of prophylactic antibiotics in our study but the SSI rate was low.

codes.summary: The overall SSI rate after emergency cesarean section in this rural Rwandan hospital was 4%, lower than expected and similar to rates in middle-income countries.

evidence_quotes.quote: The overall prevalence of SSI in our population was 4.00%, which was surprisingly low compared to the baseline assumptions, which were calculated based on the literature available from other African countries.
evidence_quotes.section: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups

provenance.section_heading: Incidence of surgical site infection in both groups
provenance.text_snippet: The overall prevalence of SSI in our population was 4.00%

codes.summary: Rigorous infection control measures and proper timing of prophylactic antibiotics may have contributed to the low SSI rate observed.

evidence_quotes.quote: The overall observed low rate SSI in our Study might have been a result of some good practices in infections prevention practices which were systematic in Ruhengeri Hospital. These included adequate timing of prophylactic antibiotics as all women were given the first doses before they enter the operating room ensuring antibiotics are given before skin incision as recommended.

provenance.text_snippet: good practices in infections prevention practices which were systematic in Ruhengeri Hospital

codes.summary: Provider preference for extended antibiotic regimens and workload limited enrollment and adherence to protocol.

evidence_quotes.quote: Some of the challenges which contributed to the limitation of our study included providers related factors; some of the healthcare providers preferred to stick on their routine practice of using extended dose of antibiotics or a packed workload prevented them from enrolling many women who were eligible to participate in the study.

provenance.text_snippet: providers preferred to stick on their routine practice of using extended dose of antibiotics
No risk of bias tool or assessment reported.

notes_flags.detail: Wound class not specified; ascertainment of SSI based on study-defined criteria.
